alert.note: Alert for Norman (Minnesota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks (Northeastern North Dakota and Northwestern Minnesota)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued April 15 at 10:43AM CDT until April 20 at 10:00PM CDT by NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in North Dakota...Minnesota... Red River of the North at Fargo affecting Cass and Clay Counties. Red River of the North near Hickson affecting Cass County. Wild Rice River (MN) at Hendrum affecting Norman County. Snake River AT Alvarado affecting Marshall County. Wild Rice River (ND) near Abercrombie affecting Richland County. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Minnesota...North Dakota... Marsh River at Shelly affecting Norman County. Snake River below Warren affecting Marshall County. Roseau River at Roseau affecting Roseau County. Red River of the North at Wahpeton affecting Wilkin and Richland Counties. South Branch Buffalo River at Sabin affecting Clay County. Buffalo River near Dilworth affecting Clay County. Buffalo River near Hawley affecting Clay County. Wild Rice River (MN) at Twin Valley affecting Norman County. Two Rivers River near Hallock affecting Kittson County. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. ...FLOOD WARNING FOR SNOWMELT NOW IN EFFECT FROM TUESDAY AFTERNOON TO LATE THURSDAY EVENING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Marsh River at Shelly. * WHEN...From Tuesday afternoon to late Thursday evening. * IMPACTS...At 14.0 feet, MINOR FLOOD STAGE. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:30 AM CDT Saturday the stage was 4.6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage early Tuesday afternoon to a crest of 14.1 feet Tuesday evening. It will then fall below flood stage Wednesday afternoon. - Flood stage is 14.0 feet. &&
info.instruction: Safety message - Turn around, don`t drown. Don`t travel through flooded areas. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
